pair.Prompt: Northern Securities Company v. United States (193 U.S. 197)
pair.Response: Response: In this case, the Northern Securities Company was formed under the laws of New Jersey with an authorized capital of $400,000,000 for the purpose of promoting the interests of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company and its connections. The defendants James J. Hill and J. Pierpont Morgan sold a large amount of Great Northern stock to the defendant at $180 per share in exchange for stock of the defendant at par. The defendant J. P. Morgan and other shareholders of the Northern Pacific Company sold to the defendant a majority of the stock of the Northern Pacific Company. No change took place in the management of the railway companies as a result of the formation of the Northern Securities Company.
